Q0.reasoning: The clinical note explicitly states whole exome sequencing (WES) has been requested to investigate a genetic cause of cholestatic liver disease.

Q1.reasoning: UHC WES coverage criteria do not impose a strict age cutoff for exome testing; pediatric patients are generally eligible so no age-based exclusion applies to this 10-year-old.

Q2.reasoning: UHC policy does not restrict WES orders to a specific specialty (any qualified ordering clinician may request testing), so there is no specific specialty requirement that the oncologist fails to meet.

Q3.reasoning: Patient has unexplained conjugated hyperbilirubinemia/cholestatic liver disease with a family history suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism and prior nondiagnostic testing; these facts meet UHC criteria for WES when a genetic etiology is suspected and prior testing is non-diagnostic.

Q4.reasoning: UHC often expects prior targeted testing when a single-gene diagnosis is strongly suspected, but for heterogeneous presentations like pediatric cholestasis WES is appropriate after nondiagnostic CMA; a CMA was performed and was nondiagnostic, satisfying prior-test expectations for this scenario.

Q5.reasoning: There is a documented family history of an inborn error of metabolism in a cousin, which is relevant to eligibility under UHC criteria that consider family history of genetic disease.

Q6.reasoning: UHC WES guidance requires documentation of pre-test genetic counseling or counseling by a qualified provider; the record states there is no documentation of pre-test genetic counseling, so this requirement is unmet.

Q7.reasoning: CPT 81415 corresponds to clinical whole exome sequencing (proband-only) and is the appropriate code for the requested WES.

Q8.reasoning: Although the clinical indication, prior nondiagnostic CMA, and family history support medical necessity under UHC WES criteria, lack of documented pre-test genetic counseling (a UHC requirement) prevents meeting all coverage conditions; therefore coverage is not approved.
